text:
today on hot thai kitchen we are making spicy 
shrimp cake Sawaddee ka welcome to hot Thai kitchen the

end of the year is coming up real fast so today 
I'm going to share with you a great appetizer

for your Christmas or New Year's party or whatever 
you're doing we're making something called Tod mun

goong which is our shrimp cake however this isn't 
quite the traditional shrimp cake recipe I'm doing

a hybrid recipe between our traditional fish 
cake and shrimp cake combining the best of both

worlds so you'll see how when we go to make it 
but first here's your thai lesson tod means

to deep fry Mun it has several meanings but I 
think the intended meaning for this recipe is

fatty which would make sense because the original 
shrimp cake recipe has a lot of pork fat in it and

finally goong you may already know means shrimp and 
so let's take a look at our ingredients 300 grams

of peels and deveined shrimp 1 egg 3 tablespoons 
of red curry paste you can use store-bought paste

or make your own you can use a little less if 
you want it less spicy 1/4 cup of coconut milk

about 1 TSP of fish sauce 1 TSP of sugar 3 kaffir 
lime leaves Center rib removed then very thinly

julienned half a cup of chopped string beans you 
can also use a combination of corn and string

beans which is what I am doing about 2 cups of 
panko or Japanese style breadcrumbs so the flavor

combination of the red curry paste the kaffir lime 
leaves and the string beans are traditional of our

fish cakes or our thought Munt blah now while our 
fish cakes are delicious they look like this and

they're not the prettiest thing to serve at a 
party our shrimp cakes on the other hand are

beautiful because of breaded in breadcrumbs and 
they taste good even after they've come down to

room temperature but the flavor isn't quite 
as interesting as the fish cakes so I'm doing

shrimp cakes but borrowing the flavors from our 
fish cakes so the first thing we need to do is

to go and saute our curry we're going to first 
saute our curry paste now this is my trick it's

not traditional most of the time in Thailand they 
just put in the raw curry paste into the mix but

we know that's sauteing the paste like toasting 
spices booms up the flavor so we're going to do

that so we're going to start with a quarter of a 
cup of coconut milk we're going to bring that to

a simmer and reduce it down by about half just to 
get rid of the excess liquid so it doesn't make

our mixture too runny and the coconut milk is 
also my trick it's not very traditional but the

traditional recipe uses about 30% lard which is 
way more pork fat than I'm willing to eat so I'm

replacing pork fat with coconut fat because the 
fat helps tenderize the mixture a little bit and

it helps make the texture a little bit nicer and 
soft so you know this is healthier so just going

to bring it to a boil and let it reduce a little 
bit and we're going in with our curry paste and

we're not trying to separate the coconut oil here 
like when we make curry we're just cooking the

curry paste and reducing excess liquid so just 
keep cooking it until it becomes a thick paste

so now that our curry paste has cooled down we're 
going to mix everything together in the bulk so

we've got here our curry paste that's cooled down 
a bit string beans in the corn now the string

beans are quite traditional the corn isn't the 
corn is my thing because I like corn so I added

it but you can just do string beans now the string 
beans are actually quite important in a sense that

it's a crunch element it will add textural variety 
which makes a difference in something that's quite

dense such as a shrimp cake the kaffir lime 
leaves now I'm going to stress that you have

to slice them very very thinly because these 
leaves are tough they don't soften throughout

the cooking process and so unless you cut it very 
finely it's kind of uncomfortable to eat and then

we're going to go in with the sugar and then 
fish sauce now fish sauce I'm using a teaspoon

this is going to depend on how salty your curry 
paste is you may need a little bit less you may

need a little bit more so for the first time 
you make it I recommend mixing everything up

including the shrimp cook up a little bit of the 
batter and then taste it to see how salty it is

to begin with see if you need to add fish sauce 
and if so how much so on and so forth okay so

now that we've got everything we're going to go 
and grind our shrimp and I didn't want to grind

the shrimp until the last minute because they want 
to keep the shrimp very very cold in the fridge so

our shrimp into here and I'm using this dinky 
little food processor traditionally before the

age of technology they used to pound the shrimp 
using mortar and pestle believe it or not and then

one egg in there and the egg is going to lighten 
up the texture and it's also the fat from the yolk

is going to add some richness to the mixture 
and it will tenderize the mixture a little bit

so I need to talk about this because it could mess 
up your recipe it's best to use fresh shrimp for

this because frozen shrimp always come with 
a layer of ice glazed around them and when

you saw this excess water is going to make your 
mixture too runny and you won't be able to form

them which I discovered the hard way so if you 
absolutely have to use frozen shrimp take them

out and thaw them a day ahead of time drain them 
off and lay them on a tray with lots of paper

towel so they dry off leave them in the fridge 
overnight uncovered so that the water around the

shrimp evaporates overnight and then you'll be 
able to use it the next day make sure that you

leave that tray of shrimp on the bottom shelf 
of the fridge and away from your other food to

prevent cross-contamination another important 
point the recipe calls for 300 grams of shrimp

if you're buying frozen make sure you buy at 
least one pound because that pound may include

the weight of the ice glace which means once 
you thaw it you'll end up with less shrimp and

the same applies if you're buying shell on fresh 
shrimp remember to account for the weight of the

shells so for the dipping sauce since the shrimp 
cakes are primarily salty and spicy we're going

to make a sweet and sour dipping sauce so it can 
balance it all out so let's take a look at our

ingredients a quarter cup of sugar a quarter 
cup of white vinegar one clove of garlic once

per Chile or peachy fat chopped into small pieces 
you can also use any other large red chili pepper

a pinch of salt one tide chili this is optional 
in case you want to make it extra spicy one to

two tablespoons of ground peanuts and this is 
also optional hey first we're going to take

your Chili's and your garlic and pound it all 
down so we we're ready what we're doing pretty

much juicing it so the chiles don't remain in a 
big chunk it incorporates in corporated into the

dipping sauce just going to pound it down into a 
paste okay so that's kind of what we're looking

for here a rough paste and now we're going to 
add all this into our pot we're going to add our

sugar into this our little pinch of salt and then 
our vinegar since there's a lot of chili juice in

here I'm going to pour it in here that way I don't 
waste any chilly bits so we're just going to bring

this to a simmer and let it simmer for about two 
to three minutes what we want here is to cook the

garlic cook everything else but more importantly 
to get it to the consistency that we need which

is a syrupy consistency now the problem is this 
when it's hot will always be runny ER than it is

when it's cold so for this amount of time I mean 
for this amount of stuff it's going to take two to

three minutes of simmering if you are making 
more you're not sure you can always test the

consistency by putting a little bit of it into a 
ramekin stick the ramekin in the freezer and once

it's cooled down just check to see how how thick 
it is now so now that our dipping sauce is ready

to go we're going to get ready to shape our shrimp 
cake so we can fry them now to be efficient you

want to portion them all out first before you 
shape and bread them okay so pour [ __ ] good

portioning tool is one of these scoops right here 
you don't have it you can also use a tablespoon

because we're going to need about a tablespoon 
worth of material of no substance of shrimp cake

now we're ready to shape them now to prevent 
these from sticking to your hands you always

want to have a little water bowl so you can wet 
your hands and that'll be the nonstick trick now

traditionally these are made into patties but 
I'm going to do bowls because bowls are cuter

for parties and if you're going to do bowls just 
roll them into balls shape ish don't do any bigger

than that because if you make bigger balls in 
that you know have a hard time cooking on the

outside will burn by the time you cook the inside 
if you want bigger pieces make them into patties

and in fact in Thailand they sometimes like to 
poke a hole in the middle and make them like

little Donuts but we're going to do balls so but 
you can do whatever you want drop them in there

okay and now that you've maxed out the surface 
a little bit we're going to toss them into the

bread crumbs using this spoon so you don't get 
your so you don't get your hands sticky again

oil at 350 it's quite important that you keep the 
temperature consistent because if it's too hot it

will start to burn the outside before before 
the inside cooks and if it's too cold it'll

start absorbing oil too much if you drop something 
and it's not looking like it's not bubbling very

excitedly its bubbling just kind of lazily your 
oil is too cold a thermometer really helps you

keep it somewhere between 325 to 375 you know 
hovering around there you're not going to get

it exactly 350 every time you should be okay so 
these will take few minutes it's hard to say I

never I've never actually timed it but just a 
few minutes but you can tell based on just the

color we're really going by the color of this at 
this point if the color of the panco was done and

the inside of it is not done that means you have 
the pieces are too big either that or the oil is

too hot now remember too that because the shrimp 
mixture has curry paste mixed into it it's going

to be a little darker to begin with so we're not 
really looking for golden brown we're looking for

a nice brown color on these and they're going 
to puff up a lot bigger than they normally are

and they're going to start to crack a little bit 
take these out these looks done to me and now if

you're not sure they're done take them out and let 
them cool because residual heating will keep them

cooking then cut one open so don't cut them open 
as soon as you take them out of the pan cut them

open after they've shrunken back to their original 
size and then you can see if it's not cooked in

the inside that means you have some adjusting to 
do so our shrimp balls are done here's what it

looks like on the inside okay and so the good 
thing about these is they also reheat really

well so if you need to take them to somebody 
else's house for a party just put them in the

oven at 400 degrees six to eight minutes should 
do it and they'll taste almost as good as when

they're freshly fry so I'm just going to finish 
our dipping sauce here with some peanuts that's

been roasted and crushed and just going to stir 
that in and it just adds some nuttiness you don't

have to finish it off with some extra cilantro 
then we're going to dish it into our little sauce

bowl here and I save just enough cilantro so I 
can do that fine a little bit just enough okay

so that's going on here now I've used for a good 
color contrast I've used banana leaves which you

can find frozen in Asian grocery stores also it 
stops them from rolling around so it's served

double purpose just want to pile them up on here 
and the good thing about these is they stay hot

for a really long time it's good thing because for 
a party you want them to stay hot for a long time

and that's it that is our thought mango or our 
Christmas special shrimp appetizer hope you get a

chance to make this at your party and for the full 
written recipe you can visit at hsn.com and you

like the show please click to subscribe and I will 
see you next time for your next delicious time
